utterances: You know, that's that's why I felt like this song was important because it goes to the heart of that sense of community and how everybody just helped everyone.
Do you have any - forgive me for asking, but do you have any survivors guilt?
Is there a part of you that feels - it's just - you're kind of - it's not enough?
I can tell you that I felt really guilty that I wasn't there as it was happening.
But honestly, after the storms, it wasn't a place to be.
We were flying planes down to try to get people off, especially pregnant people or elderly or people that had injuries because there was no hospital, and we had to just get people off.
And - but there were people there that didn't want to leave because they wanted to stay and help.
And a lot of my friends and my own family felt guilty for leaving.
But for a little while - well, not for a little, while for a couple of months, it was several months - it wasn't a healthy place to be, to honest with you.
Well, how are things now?
You know, I think the recovery is going to be measured in years.
You know, it'll be a year September 6 that these storms happened, believe it or not.
And it gets better.
You can just tell it's been hit really hard, and it's not going to recover at once.
And you can still tell that it's broken a little bit at its core, you know.
Kenny Chesney.
His latest album, ""Songs For The Saints,"" is out now.
Kenny Chesney, thanks so much for talking with us.
Thanks for having me.
(SOUNDBITE OF VIDEO)
(Singing) I ain't lonely, but I spend a lot of time alone.
After our conversation, Kenny Chesney sent us a video.
In it, he plays an acoustic version of ""Love For Love City"" overlooking the island of St. John from the concrete slab where his house once stood.
You can see that video on our website, npr.org.
Lieutenant Colonel Eric Kruger was one of the highest-ranking soldiers killed in Iraq.
He died in Baghdad with two other soldiers when a roadside bomb blew up the Humvee they were riding in.
Last week there was a memorial held for Lieutenant Colonel Kruger at Fort Carson, Colorado.
Eric Whitney of member station KRCC in Colorado Springs was there.
Eric John Kruger was 40 years old and already a veteran of four combat operations by the time he went to Iraq.
He was a graduate of the Army's elite Ranger School, served at the Pentagon, in Korea, and with the Special Forces in Afghanistan.
But his fried, Lieutenant Colonel Steven Parker, said he volunteered to go to Iraq to be the deputy commander of the brigade where he started his career as an officer.
His great-grandfather served in the World War I, his grandfather in World War II, his dad in Vietnam.
So this is Eric's turn to serve.
Honor Guard, upstage.
Huh!
Most of his brigade is still in Iraq, but hundreds of soldiers came to the memorial for Lieutenant Colonel Kruger at Fort Carson and honored him with a rifle salute.
(Soundbite of rifle salute)
Lt.
Col.
PARKER: He was a guy who lived every day and certainly without regret, without fear, and with a great love of country; again, with a dedication and a love for his family.
Kruger leaves behind four children and his wife, Sarah.
Career soldiers often speak of the Army as a family, and Parker says that was especially true for Kruger.
Lt.
Col.
PARKER: And there was no separation between Eric's professional life, his family life.
His kids went to work with him.
His son's middle name is Armistice.
He was born on Veteran's Day.
There was no real separation between this patriot and the parent.
You know, the father and the guy who wanted to fight for freedom.
Echo was an important ingredient.
Spector used the legendary echo chambers at Gold Star Studio in Hollywood.
Sound from the recording studio was fed to speakers inside specially constructed rooms with very thick and hard walls.
Microphones then picked up the reverberated sound in the rooms and fed them back to Spector in the control room.
(Soundbite of song, ""The Long And Winding Road"")
(Singing) The long and winding road that leads to your door…
Spector applied his wall of sound to this Beatles song.
Legend has it John Lennon invited him to do so without the knowledge of his fellow Beatle, Paul McCartney.
(Soundbite of music)
Unidentified Man #2 (Singer): (Singing) I've seen that road before…
A remix of the song that eliminates Spector's embellishments was released on an album called ""Let It Be… Naked.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) Lead me to your door.
Fans continued to argue about which version is better, but no one, it seems, doubts that Phil Spector's production techniques continue to influence the way music is made 40 years after his heyday.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) I need your love…
Steve Proffitt, NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) I need your love, darling you (unintelligible).
More to come after this.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Luke Burbank.
And I'm Alex Chadwick, in the studios of NPR East, actually: Washington, D.C.
And this is a very good day for us to have you there, Alex.
Of course, big news coming out of Washington tonight.
The president is going to make his much-anticipated speech about where things are going in Iraq.
And that's where we're going on the program today: a series of conversations I've had that grew out of an editorial meeting last week.
You remember we interviewed Congressman Duncan Hunter of California.
Right.
The outgoing chairman of the Armed Services Committee in the House.
And in that conversation, he said he has a different idea for Iraq, but it doesn't matter.
We all have to get behind the president.
The country's in trouble.
It's that question of presidential leadership that we wanted to explore.
And, of course, the question, Alex - this is what we go around and around on in these editorial meetings - is who do you talk to?
How do you find out about this stuff?
Well, I had three interviews coming up that I want you to hear.
One is with a soldier who has served in Iraq and expects to go back.
Another is with a former public official who's thought a lot about these questions of presidential leadership.
But we're going to begin with a mother, a high school principal in South Deerfield, Massachusetts.
Her name is Marty Barrett.
She has four children.
Three of them have been in Iraq on five different tours of duty.
One is still there.
I spoke with her just before the program today.
The question: presidential leadership.
Marty Barrett, the president tonight is expected to call for a surge, an increase, in American troops in Iraq.
As the mother of a son who is currently in Iraq, is that good news for you?
Well, I would like to know details as to why he wants a surge.
Thus far, I haven't heard anything to explain what he feels their mission will be, a timeline, and what specifically he hopes they'll accomplish.
So you have one son deployed in Iraq now, and two other kids who have been there and maybe would go back?
Correct.
I have another son who returned from Iraq in the fall, another son who was previously deployed.
However, he is now inactive, ready reserves.
So I don't expect him to go back to Iraq.
But my son who's currently there, he has an identical twin who could very easily go back at some point.
